column5: I just had a really long hard day, I'm sore, I'm tired, you just made it all better! So glad to hear this Brian!
Great news is always great to hear

Well that is good news Brian! Glad to hear your doing well! Looks like you got yourself some nice fishing weather for the next few days. Looking forward to seeing those reports of the silvers you have been slaying! Good luck,  Rob C

Biggest scare of your life you say. Yea loss of vision would be right up there. Well that just makes this news so much the finer. Way to go man and congrats to the docs. Great idea on treating yourself to new specs. You'll not regret that one.  Cheers
Good news, thanx for filling us in.  Amazing what the doctors are able to due.  No excuse now for tying poor knots!
Glad to hear the good news Brian. Vision loss or severe impairment would be very high on my list of unacceptable things. It would be very sad to never see a float go down again.
Great news!! An old friend of mine is dealing withvision loss from a dtached retina. Not fun. Glad to hear ypur peeper is fine!!!
Congrats Brian, you will be able to weave bacon for a long, long time, now go catch some fish
That's what I was thinking!!!  Great news man! We are all thrilled to hear it!
Thanks again gang.  Only little glimps of silver today. Woke up and changed the plan for the day. I,ll bet that was a mistake.LOL

Congrats Brian, you will be able to weave bacon for a long, long time, now go catch some fish   LOL John  When I got home, it was BBQ cleaning time. Pulled bacon and hamburg out. Got the brain going to zip it up this time. Then again, why fool with fool proof.
Great news Brian,  no excuses now for missing that float dropping !!!
Spectacular news B, so glad to hear it!

Great news me brudder...I'm still amazed how well I see now after wearing glasses for over 65 years (except when I forget where I left my reading glasses)  Maribeth goes to have one of her cataracts removed near the end of the month or in May...
Great News

Great news, I lost the use of sight in one eye for around 3 weeks once....difficult is just the beginning of that sentence.....not knowing if you are going to gain the sight back and the worry play very hard on you.  Congradulations!!!!!!!!!!!!!!   Dan
Great news!  I heard eye surgeries can be very frightening especially since you are actually awake!  I pray that you don't need any more treatment!
Great news indeed, Brian. I'm sure you'll be able to 'see your way clear' to go fishing lots in the next few months.
That is solid news Brian.  Enjoy that cleaner bill of health, some less stress and those new glasses I'm jealous you got. lol.

As many know here, I had to deal with retina detachmant last summer. The biggest scare of my life. 5 lazer surgurys, which were painful as heck. Total of 9 weeks off work.  Wouldnt of been bad being off if it was fishing related, but it was not.  Today was the first of a 5 day long weekend for me. Today was set for my visit to the eye doc, and get the toon fish ready with some rod holders, and the next 4 days to fish.  The eye has been good except for the odd days of pressure, but it was due to some stress and heavy lifting that I know I shouldnt be doing, but sometimes I just get carried away with my job. BAD BRIAN.LOL  Anyhoo, I went to the doc and had my 6 month check up since my 3 month one. I get started reading the letters and numbers one eye at a time. Right one was perfect still, left ( the detached one with glacoma) made it 4 lines. Dang, I was worried. Moved to another room for an orbital scan. Lovely lady she was.  Once done that, I have a seat and wait for the doc. He looks at the orbital scan, puts some drops in my eyes, and does his look see. I know the routine well now. Well so I thought. Usualy theres another set of drops to check further behind the eye. This was not the case today. He pulls back after having a look and says,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,  See you in 12 months. I was like ah, you sure? Yup, your eyes are good. Except for a stigment which is a dead nerve that couldnt be repaired from the lazer surgury.  I was so happy to hear this. No, exstatic is the word I am looking for here.  I was so happy, I went and treated myself to a new pair of Maui Jims uv/polerized glasses with magnafiers on the bottom for tieing my knots. I havent spent that kind of cash on sunglasses, but I dont care.  What a way to start my days off,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,  Now to tie up some roe bags for fridays fish,,,,,,,,,,,,,,  Ya I know, I dont spell so good,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,
great news bud, let fish
Absolute great news!!!
I'm happy for you...congrats
Great News Brian
Fantastic news brother. Take care of those peepers, no back ups available.
as the song goes 'I can see clearly now  . . .  Go get them B.
Glad to hear that Brian!
Hey that's is good news. Congrats and have a good weekend.
amazing news!!
Great Brian.  You will love the maui Jim's mine are so clear I hate to take them offf.
You deserve that,good for you buddy !!!
Fantastic news Brian!!
Glad to hear bud.
very nice B!

Thanks gang. Im still feeling great the from the news today.  Not sure about deserve Davey.  I am very thankfull to the doc that got me down right away to SunnyBrook right away and to see  Dr. Peter Kertes  Dr. Kertes is a vitreo-retinal surgeon at the Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre and an Associate Professor in the Department of Ophthalmology and Vision Sciences at the University of Toronto.  He specializes in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases of the retina, macula, and vitreous. He and his partners at Sunnybrook are involved in a number of clinical trials seeking better treatments for such diseases as Age-Related Macular Degeneration, Diabetic Retinopathy, as well as several surgical studies that are trying to optimize the outcomes of retinal surgery. Dr. Kertes has a special interest in international ophthalmology, notably in the realm of pediatric retinal diseases such as Retinopathy of Prematurity.  He has traveled widely in the developing world volunteering his services and expertise. He is an important contributor to the post-graduate education of ophthalmology residents and retinal fellows.
great news....
Good stuff bud!
Glad to hear Brian, that's a load off 'eh? - just in time for the annual Laker opening day with that other dood....

Lovely lady she was     Nothin wrong with your peepers now B,  just watch out for the road sweepers and the dust they create, i know ive got those sand and dust particles in my eyes before and its not pleasant  enjoy your extended weekend
But But does he know how to fish? A couple of miles up the "head" would make him see a lot better too!  Then you could say to him "did you see that"; a flash of silver
..as he picked up the hammer and saw !  Great stuff Brian... float tube pumped up yet?!
I hope to see flashes of silver in the morning.
..as he picked up the hammer and saw !  Great stuff Brian... float tube pumped up yet?!  Yes sir. I pumped it up this afternoon and added some rod holders to it. Keeping it light.
